comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: It would have been important for doctors to build up a portfolio of medical conditions and what better way to record them than photography. Such portfolios would have been used in clinical instruction. I would not be surprised if in her case, the pellagra was a direct consequence of malnutrition.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: You're right there, nobody today would be likely to want to be used as a medical exhibit while still alive!  It is a nice photo of the lady though I imagine that the full colour and digital format of today would have been more beneficial.  In the past I have seen more detailed photographs of medical conditions so doctors realised that the image could be a very useful tool in identification and education.

comment.author: 39839593@N00
comment._content: Pictures are still being made of medical conditions, but nowadays the patient's face is usually made inrecognisable.

comment.author: 16489083@N05
comment._content:
True... don't know if any of my 3 bouts with lymphoma cancer
were photojournaled but if it would help someone else in their
fight.. I would be happy to be!!!
comment.authorname: maorlando God kept us 2012 leaning on Him 2013

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 99646216@N00
comment._content: Very interesting reading up about pellagra. The dermatitis is worse in sunlight, so judging by her paler arms and chest, I'd say she's put on her best dress for the photo.

comment.author: 62153862@N00
comment._content: her hands are remarkably strong.  and look at those long, extended thumbs. she must do a lot of laundry by hand.

comment.author: 57147524@N05
comment._content: My elderly Aunt - born in Clonmel in 1935 - tells me that she is almost certain the woman in question is Mrs Casey from Garrymore...Probably no use to you but thought I'd share it anyway!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/57147524@N05] Hi Paddy, and sorry for slow reply! Absolutely of use to us. If your aunt is right, then the name Mrs Casey and Garrymore may well jog somebody else's memory. Please thank your aunt very much for us!
